witnesses.name: Jean Humbert
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: former neighbor, lived in same house 7-8 years ago

testimony.quarrel_subject: Her son Jean Gontart called her witch and accused her of causing his father's death

witnesses.name: Jeanne femme Jean Flaman le jeune
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: former tenant, lived in Jeanne's house for 3 years

testimony.quarrel_subject: Witness suggested illness at Visage d'Ange house might be witchcraft; servant reported this to Jehenne

witnesses.name: Magdelaine fille feu Florentin Pernot (surnommé Visage d'Ange)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Found a new carolus in ashes outside Jehenne's house; daughter-in-law asked for return but mother refused
testimony.threat_quote: Je n'en diray mot pour cela mais tu verras ce que s'en sera

witnesses.name: Pierre Roussel
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: former tenant, lived with her for 2 years

witnesses.name: Jacquot Arnoult
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: contracted to take her on pilgrimage

testimony.quarrel_subject: Dispute about waiting to see curé during pilgrimage to chapel of St Anne

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: beginning 3 or 4 months after the journey

witnesses.name: Vacharin Gaulthier
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: former servant to Mengin Claude, neighbor

testimony.quarrel_subject: Threw stones at her when she was talking to herself in garden; she called him 'O grand fuzelier de Vacharin'
Her son threatened her about going to court
Dispute between Jeanne and her daughter-in-law over beating of small child

witnesses.name: Balthazar la Hyre
witnesses.location: previously Neufchâteau, now living at Secqvaulx

testimony.quarrel_subject: Confronted her with stick about son's illness; later confronted again threatening to hang her
testimony.threat_quote: que par la mort et par la chair dieu, qu'elle estoit sorciere, et qu'elle avoit faict malade son enfant, que s'elle ne le guarissoit, qu'il l'assommeroit toute a l'heure

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: around same time as son's illness

timeline.subject: Jeanne Magnien
timeline.details: At request of PG des Vosges. General repute as witch, claim she made several people ill

timeline.subject: Jeanne Magnien
timeline.details: Procureur general des Vosges asks for arrest and interrogation

timeline.subject: Jeanne Magnien
timeline.details: Interrogation and confrontation with Balthazar la Hyre

timeline.subject: Jeanne Magnien
timeline.details: Confrontations about episode with possessed girl

timeline.subject: Jean Gontar
timeline.details: Interrogation of her son - said he did not believe she was a witch

timeline.subject: Jeanne Magnien
timeline.details: Procureur general asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Jeanne Magnien
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to torture, with moderation appropriate for her age

timeline.subject: Jeanne Magnien
timeline.details: Given thumbscrews on hands and feet, placed on la chable. Made no admission

timeline.subject: Jeanne Magnien
timeline.details: After being prevented from sleeping all night. Still denying everything. Prepared for renewed torture but apparently not tortured despite threats

timeline.subject: Jeanne Magnien
timeline.details: Procureur general des Vosges suggests she be renvoyée jusqu'a rappel

torture.restrictions: with moderation appropriate for her age

accomplices_named.name: Huguette
accomplices_named.context: Mentioned as having accused Jeanne; described as 'bruslée sorciere' (burned witch)

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeanne Magnien to Magdelaine's mother
notable_quotes.french: Je n'en diray mot pour cela mais tu verras ce que s'en sera
notable_quotes.english: I won't say a word about it but you will see what comes of it
notable_quotes.context: Threat after mother refused to return the carolus coin found by daughter

notable_quotes.speaker: Anne femme Mengin Claude (reporting Jehenne's words)
notable_quotes.french: Tenez Annon baillez cela a vos enfans
notable_quotes.english: Here Annon give this to your children
notable_quotes.context: Giving millet and tart to sick children

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeanne Magnien
notable_quotes.french: qui t'a faict malade te guairisse, je ne suis pas une guairisseuse ny faiseuse de maladie, c'est affaire aux genaulches de guairir et de faire malade
notable_quotes.english: Let whoever made you sick cure you, I am not a healer nor maker of illness, it is the business of witches to cure and to make sick
notable_quotes.context: Response when asked to heal someone

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Gontar (Jeanne's son) to Henry Melnie
notable_quotes.french: Que par la mort dieu, s'elle s'en va plaindre, je luy feray mectre la main sur le colet, qu'elle ne resveille pas le char qui dort
notable_quotes.english: By God's death, if she goes to complain, I will have her arrested, that she not awaken the sleeping cart
notable_quotes.context: Son threatening mother about going to court

notable_quotes.speaker: Vacharin Gaulthier (reporting what Jehenne said to herself)
notable_quotes.french: Tien tu, ostes tu, petit cocquinel, laisse my
notable_quotes.english: Take that, remove that, little cocquinel, leave me
notable_quotes.context: Talking to herself in garden when witness saw her

notable_quotes.speaker: Balthazar la Hyre to Jeanne
notable_quotes.french: que par la mort et par la chair dieu, qu'elle estoit sorciere, et qu'elle avoit faict malade son enfant, que s'elle ne le guarissoit, qu'il l'assommeroit toute a l'heure
notable_quotes.english: By God's death and flesh, that she was a witch and had made his child sick, and if she didn't cure him, he would kill her right there
notable_quotes.context: Threatening her with stick in garden about his sick son

relationships.evidence_text: had been married first to Claude Gontart
then 13 years later to Mansuy Magnien, masson et laboureur, who had died 9 years earlier
her son Jean Gontart, also weaver
Jeanne femme Jean Flaman le jeune
Vacharin Gaulthier, serviteur a Bastien Clement
Had lived for 10 months in her house
occupied small house belonging to Jehenne and adjoining hers

economic_context.details: Jeanne had transferred property to her son, allegedly because she was almost blind and could not manage her own affairs. Witnesses disputed timing of transfer, suggesting it happened right after accusation by Huguette. There was a previous dispute with Balthazar la Hyre about a stolen 'ciel du lit' (bed canopy) 16 years before. Quarrel with daughter-in-law about vine killed by hot water. Son threatened to evict her from house.

harms_catalog.harm_description: Swellings to head and neck, swollen legs, no appetite, still very sick 3 years later
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Servant reported that witness suggested illness might be witchcraft; Jehenne's daughter-in-law beat servant

harms_catalog.harm_description: Swollen testicles, crying like a dog day and night, aged 2 months. Recovered after visit to hospital
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Jeanne initially refused to visit, then came and inspected child

harms_catalog.harm_description: Became ill and died in 8 days
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Mother refused to return carolus coin found by daughter

harms_catalog.harm_description: Twisted neck and damaged arms and legs, apostume on neck that spread to head and body
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Carolus coin incident and earlier quarrel about vine killed by hot water

harms_catalog.victim_name: Two small children of Mengin Claude
harms_catalog.harm_description: Both became ill, then slowly recovered after Jehenne brought millet and tart
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Brought millet in 'ung saulssure bien noire' and tart, children recovered after eating

harms_catalog.harm_description: Became ill, all swollen, died after 2 years
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jehenne hated the girl for no known reason

harms_catalog.harm_description: Lost horses, including fine one that would not obey but became docile when passed to someone else
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Dispute during pilgrimage about waiting to see curé
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: beginning 3 or 4 months after the journey

harms_catalog.harm_description: Became ill with an enflure (swelling) that lasted more than 6 months
Children aged 6 and 2 died after becoming emaciated despite continuing to eat
Body all twisted, illness still returned periodically

harms_catalog.victim_name: Son aged 6 of Balthazar la Hyre
harms_catalog.harm_description: All bunched up and unable to stretch himself out, could sometimes talk sometimes not, virtually unable to eat. Recovered within 4-5 days after Jehenne promised cure
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Jeanne promised child would recover after being confronted with stick

harms_catalog.harm_description: Strange sickness that began in shoulders then affected arms and legs at different times. Cured within a week after Jehenne said he would recover
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: around same time as son's illness
harms_catalog.method_alleged: After threatening to hang her, she told him it was caused by cold and he would soon recover

harms_catalog.victim_name: Small child of Balthazar la Hyre
harms_catalog.harm_description: Fell out of cradle at bottom of bed
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: when wife upbraided Jehenne for inappropriate remarks

material_culture.context: New carolus found in ashes outside Jehenne's house by Magdelaine, given to mother, daughter-in-law asked for return
Brought by Jehenne in 'ung saulssure bien noire' as gift for sick children, said to be from wedding feast of her niece
Brought with millet as gift for sick children
Stolen from Jeanne 16 years before; she accused Balthazar la Hyre of taking it
Balthazar la Hyre had stick in hand when he confronted Jehenne about his sick son
Balthazar threatened to hang Jehenne from pear tree with a garter
Applied to Jehenne's hands and feet during torture
Jeanne placed on this device during torture

spatial_references.context: Location of trial and residence of accused and most witnesses
Street where Jehenne lived and had reputation as witch
Pilgrimage destination near village of Goudancy for eye treatment from spring
Village near Jouvelle in Burgundy where chapel of St Anne located
Pilgrimage site visited by Jehenne for eye trouble
Pilgrimage site allegedly advised by Jehenne for sick child (she denied this)
Where witness took sick child who then recovered same evening
Where Balthazar la Hyre was living at time of testimony
Place where Magdelaine was spinning before finding the carolus

economic_hardship_indicators: Jeanne lived by spinning after husband's death
Multiple families living in same house (weavers)
Jeanne almost blind and unable to manage affairs

prior_legal_disputes.description: 16 years before, Jeanne accused Balthazar la Hyre of stealing a 'ciel du lit' (bed canopy) when she had been absent

legal_context.redress_outcome: On second visit to Goudance, asked curé to secure redress against accusations but he asked if she had permission from her curé, which she had to admit she did not
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Guarded in her house by arbalestriers after being accused. Prevented from sleeping all night before final interrogation on 29 July 1611

change_de_nancy.modification_details: Approved torture with moderation appropriate for her age

hearsay_chains.content: calling her witch, accusing her of causing father's death
that witness had accused her of witchcraft
said Jehenne had bewitched her parents
that curé did come later that evening for conjurations

emotional_state_notes: very pertinacious and arrogant (judges' observation during confrontation)
bon courage (judges remarked on her courage during torture)
stoutly denying everything after sleep deprivation
undressed herself and placed herself in position for renewed torture

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Denied everything absolutely. Said Balthazar la Hyre had reputation as 'un debauche' and she had accused him of theft 16 years before
Denied advising pilgrimage to Saint Memefort
Agreed to carolus episode but denied making threat

third_parties.name: Jean Gontart
third_parties.relationship_to_accused: son (from first marriage to Claude Gontart)
third_parties.context: Called her witch, accused her of causing his father's death, threatened her about going to court, interrogated and said he did not believe she was a witch

third_parties.name: daughter-in-law of Jeanne
third_parties.context: Beat servant, had quarrels with Jehenne, beat her small child roughly, pushed Jehenne into room and locked her in

third_parties.name: Huguette
third_parties.context: Previously accused Jeanne of witchcraft, described as 'bruslée sorciere' (burned witch), already executed

third_parties.name: sister of Demenge Guyet
third_parties.context: Came complaining of bad leg asking Jehenne to heal her

third_parties.name: curé of Goudance
third_parties.context: Jehenne asked him to secure redress against accusations, he performed exorcisms on possessed people

third_parties.name: possessed blind girl with demon called Joly
third_parties.context: Dancing and singing at church, touched Jehenne on shoulder and shook her during Mass

third_parties.name: Henry Melnie
third_parties.context: Jean Gontart told him about threats to his mother

third_parties.name: Nicolas Lalleman
third_parties.context: Jehenne threatened to leave house and go live with him

third_parties.name: Florentin Pernot (Visage d'Ange)
third_parties.context: Died in 8 days after illness, death attributed to Jehenne

third_parties.name: Mansuy Magnien
third_parties.context: Masson et laboureur, died 9 years before trial 'des esprinsons'

extraction_metadata.notes: This trial is particularly significant as it resulted in release despite torture. Jeanne Magnien was a 65-year-old widow who maintained her innocence throughout extensive interrogations, confrontations, and torture. She was released 'jusqu'a rappel' (until recalled) on 31 July 1611. The case features detailed testimony about her reputation in rue Verdunoise, multiple alleged harms following quarrels, an interesting pilgrimage episode involving possessed people at Goudance, and family conflicts with her son and daughter-in-law. The trial demonstrates a pattern of healing/harming accusations typical of witchcraft cases, with neighbors seeking her help then blaming her when things went wrong. Her resistance to torture and consistent denials, combined with her son's testimony that he did not believe she was a witch, likely contributed to her release. The document provides rich detail on daily life, neighborhood dynamics, material culture, and the legal process including multiple confrontations and judicial oversight by the Change de Nancy.
